settings.question: What are the 4 Cs of Diamonds?
settings.answer:
The 4 Cs—Carat, Clarity, Cut, and Color—are the appraisal standards used to grade diamonds:

  • Carat is the diamond's weight.
  • Clarity describes how free a diamond is from inclusions and blemishes.
  • Cut describes the quality of the faceting of the diamond in relation to its ability to emit sparkle.
  • Color describes how free of color the diamond is, with colorless diamonds graded D being the most expensive.

settings.question: What is Diamond Certification and Why is it Important?
settings.answer: The Rule of Certification is a guiding principle followed by all members of the GEMOLOGICAL LABORATORY. It implies that all gem grades and information about them may only be included in reports published by the laboratory which has graded the gems. Effective certification is considered one of the best methods of preventing gem-related fraud and deception. Transparent and self-sufficient certifications provide obvious benefits to the client. Thus, you will always know constantly about the valuables that are being housed in the collection and what its value is. It is however sad to note that there are some people who choose to abuse this kind of information.

settings.question: What’s the Difference Between Natural and Lab-Grown Diamonds?
settings.answer: Lab-grown diamonds are produced inside an enclosure under highly controlled conditions using technology. On the other hand, natural diamonds are formed over a long period of time, sometimes millions of years, under the Earth. All diamonds in terms of composition are the same, however, lab-grown diamonds are more convenient and cheaper especially since there is no mining.

settings.question: How Do I Know Which Diamond Is Right for Me?
settings.answer: All of us have been there whereby after we fall in love, we make several purchases primarily of rings including engagement rings. As a tip for selecting a diamond ring, it will be wise for you first to question oneself what the 4Cs of diamonds mean to you in order of importance. Do you want to have a big carat diamond or do you want a nice brilliant cut? Think of the style and the amount of money you have and find a good certified diamond seller. Depending on the settings it is often advisable also to consider the tastes of the wearer fiancé in case of an engagement ring.

settings.question: How Do I Read a Diamond Certificate?
settings.answer: Diamond certificates contain the carat weight and other grades of the diamond such as cut, clarity, color and some features that can distinguish the diamond. In understanding the parameters of grading differently shaped diamonds, focus on considering the cut clarity thickness chips etc. and grading the overall diamond from an aesthetic perspective which usually includes clarity and cut stones. Ensure you check on those reports as GIA or AGS accredited laboratories.

settings.question: What Is the Best Diamond Cut for an Engagement Ring?
settings.answer: Which cut of diamond is the best mostly depends on the individual’s style and the intended use of the diamond setting. The Round Brilliant Cut is the most loved cut as it has sparkle and indeed has not gone out of style. Other cuts like Princess, Emerald as well as Cushion have a different cut and so may appeal to some people more than others. Most importantly, one must ensure that the diamond’s cut is a good grade because it determines how well the light can be refracted from the diamond.

settings.question: Can Lab-Grown Diamonds Be Used for Engagement Rings?
settings.answer: Definitely, yes. Engagement rings can also include lab-created diamonds. They are similar in terms of beauty, strength, and appearance to the natural diamonds but are usually much cheaper and have less detrimental effects on the environment. Another thing is lab-grown diamonds are certified and have various shapes and sizes which are ideal for engagement rings.

settings.question: How Do I Maintain My Diamond Jewelry?
settings.answer:
If you want to maintain optimum appearance of your diamond jewelry:

  • Once in a while, it is advisable to clean your diamonds with some mild soap and water and a soft bristle hair brush.
  • To avoid scratching, keep each diamond in a separate soft lined compartment of a jewelry box.
  • From time to time, bring in your jewelry for maintenance checks to make sure the diamond is intact and no damage is apparent.

settings.question: Are There Ethical Diamonds?
settings.answer: Yes, ethical diamonds or human rights resistant diamonds are those that have been mined without harming people or the environment. Today, lab made diamonds have become an elastoplastic substitute for diamond with the ability to recycle its waste reused as raw material without adverse environmental effects. Furthermore, some jewelers sell diamonds that have been guaranteed to be sourced from regions at conflict.

settings.question: What Are Fancy Color Diamonds?
settings.answer: Fancy color diamonds are diamonds which are naturally colored and come in colors such as blue, pink, green, yellow and many more. Fancy colored diamonds evaluation is based on the characteristic of hue, tone and saturation of the color. The intensity of the color increases the worth of the diamond because high quality diamonds have rare and extreme colors. Fancy color diamonds are both beautiful and rare stones, which makes them perfect for someone in search of an unusual jewel.

settings.question: How Do I Choose Between Different Diamond Shapes?
settings.answer:
When it comes to the shape of a diamond, the style and choices of the one who will wear the ring should be of utmost importance:

  • Round is traditional and the most universal shape which quickly occupies the center of attention.
  • Princess is somewhere in the middle being younger with a square or rectangular dimension
  • Emerald appears as an old fashioned cut which is very graceful made by a step cut
  • Cushion looks gentle and classic, with all corners smoothened

The Oval shape appears beautiful and adds the illusion of the diamond being bigger. Pick a shape that pleases you and the design of the ring as certain shapes are compatible with certain styles.

settings.question: What is the Carat Weight of a Diamond?
settings.answer: Carat is a weight measurement that is specific to diamonds. 1 carat is equivalent to 200 milligrams. All things being equal, larger diamonds are usually more costly, but, carat weight is not the only factor to evaluate the value of a diamond. There are also other aspects that need to be looked at, such as the cut, clarity, and color, which help ascertain the true valuation of the diamond.

settings.question: How Are Diamonds Graded?
settings.answer: The diamonds are graded on the basis of the 4 Cs, that is, Carat, Clarity, Cut, and Color by a certified gemologist. The grade refers to the quality of the diamond in these particular six factors aforementioned. Acclaimed grading bodies such as the Gemological Institute of America (GIA) and the American Gem Society (AGS) issue certifications that give an extensive coverage on a diamond grading.

settings.question: What Should I Know Before Buying a Diamond Engagement Ring?
settings.answer:
However, the particular still need to keep the following checklist in mind before purchasing an engagement ring.

  • Set a budget: Spend this amount to see what you can get for it before descending into the engagement ring buying abyss.
  • Understand the 4 Cs: Carat, clarity, cut, and color and how they affect the quality and the cost of the diamond
  • Consider the setting: The setting of the ring will affect the appearance of the diamond and therefore pick a setting that will enhance the beauty of the diamond.
  • Know your partner's preferences: Consider their jewelry preferences, modern or otherwise; if they have a preference for vintage, modern or classic looks go for the least classic style.

With these aspects in mind, picking out the ideal diamond engagement ring would pose no challenge.

settings.code:
Diamond Education

Learn about 4C's and basics.

settings.description:
DIAMOND SHAPE

Diamond shape is the most visual characteristic. It is the diamond’s outline and comes in many forms such as round cut, princess cut, cushion cut, etc.

DIAMOND CARAT

Diamond carat is its weight and reflects the diamond’s size. The larger the diamond, the rarer and more valuable it becomes. Carat is the most visible C.

DIAMOND COLOR

Graded on a scale from D to Z, diamond color is its degree of colorlessness or tint of yellow/brown. The more colorless, the rarer and higher the value of the diamond.

DIAMOND CLARITY

Diamond carat is its weight and reflects the diamond’s size. The larger the diamond, the rarer and more valuable it becomes. Carat is the most visible C.

Our diamond education is the most comprehensive diamond buying guide, designed to answer all your questions. We address the4 C’s of diamonds(carat, cut, color and clarity) and beyond so you can make a prudent diamond buying decision, while maximizing your diamond’s appearance and value. Diamonds are considered the world's most precious gemstone.

They are traditionally used for engagement rings and other jewelry as a symbol of love and commitment. Buying a diamond is an important personal, financial and emotional decision. Our gemologists are experts on the subject and provide invaluable guidance so you can shop with confidence in a pressure free environment.

settings.text: After mastering the essentials of the 4 C’s (cut, carat, color, and clarity) of diamonds, it's time to explore more advanced aspects to enhance your selection process. At Steinhardt, our expert guides will help you navigate the detailed anatomy of diamonds, including polish, symmetry, fluorescence, girdle, culet, table, and depth. Understanding these intricate details allows you to maximize your budget and obtain the best value. Start your journey with diamond symmetry by clicking below and discover more.

settings.custom_liquid:
BEYOND THE 4 C’S

After mastering the essentials of the 4 C’s (cut, carat, color, and clarity) of diamonds, it's time to explore more advanced aspects to enhance your selection process. At Steinhardt, our expert guides will help you navigate the detailed anatomy of diamonds, including polish, symmetry, fluorescence, girdle, culet, table, and depth. Understanding these intricate details allows you to maximize your budget and obtain the best value. Start your journey with diamond symmetry by clicking below and discover more.

settings.title: Fluorescence
settings.text: Fluorescence in diamonds is evaluated based on their appearance under ultraviolet light. This phenomenon, caused by trace minerals present during the diamond's natural or lab-formed growth, results in a blue glow. Although fluorescence does not influence the diamond's look in daylight, it can affect its market value. Hence, it's important to carefully assess fluorescence, particularly concerning the diamond's color and clarity.

settings.title: Symmetry
settings.text: Symmetry refers to the precise alignment and proportion of a diamond's facets. Diamonds with excellent symmetry often achieve high cut grades. This symmetry grade is detailed on the IGI or GIA certificate.

settings.title: Polish
settings.text: Diamond polish refers to the smoothness and evenness of a diamond's facets. If the surfaces are rough, uneven, or show remnants of the original rough diamond, the quality is considered lower. Polish is a crucial factor that directly influences the diamond's cut grade. Typically, diamonds with an excellent cut grade also receive an excellent polish grade.

settings.title: Culet
settings.text: The culet is the bottom part of the diamond and should be proportionate to the diamond's shape. It plays a crucial role in how light passes through the diamond, affecting its sparkle. If the culet is not properly proportioned, it can cause light leakage, diminishing the diamond's brilliance.

settings.title: Measurements
settings.text: The measurements of a diamond play a crucial role in its sparkle and how effectively its facets display color and clarity. A well-proportioned diamond can appear more brilliant and visually appealing than a larger diamond with poor proportions. Proper proportions can also make the diamond look larger face-up, enhancing its overall beauty.

settings.title: Growth Type
settings.text: The growth type of lab-grown diamonds shapes their quality and appearance. Methods like HPHT and CVD determine how atoms arrange during crystallization, affecting clarity and color consistency. Diamonds grown under controlled conditions often boast superior brilliance and size-to-weight ratios, offering visually appealing alternatives to natural diamonds.

settings.description: Purchasing a diamond can be challenging. Our diamond buying guides are designed to offer all the necessary steps to help you make the ideal choice.

Diamond pricing can be intricate, rising exponentially with higher quality and rarity. Let us assist you in discovering the perfect diamond within your budget. As direct manufacturers, we simplify the pricing complexity for you.
Explore our extensive inventory of unique and high-quality lab-grown diamonds. Looking for something specific that we don't currently have? We offer custom cutting services to meet your needs.
All our diamonds are grown using the CVD process and are meticulously cut to achieve optimal light performance, setting industry standards for precision.

settings.title: Is there a difference between Lab Grown and Earth Mined Diamonds?
settings.text: Yes, there are differences. Lab-grown diamonds are created in labs using processes like HPHT or CVD, making them more affordable and environmentally friendly compared to earth-mined diamonds, which form naturally over billions of years and are typically more expensive due to extensive mining. Despite these differences, both types are chemically and physically almost identical.

settings.title: Will a Diamond change color over time?
settings.text: No, a diamond will not change color over time. Diamonds are highly stable and maintain their color permanently, whether they are natural or lab-grown. Proper care ensures they retain their brilliance and beauty indefinitely.

settings.title: What is better - IGI or GIA Grading?
settings.text: Both IGI (International Gemological Institute) and GIA (Gemological Institute of America) are reputable diamond grading organizations. GIA is often considered the gold standard due to its stringent grading standards and widespread recognition

settings.title: How can I be sure the certification matches the stone?
settings.text: To ensure the certification matches the stone, verify the unique laser inscription on the diamond's girdle, which corresponds to the certificate number. Additionally, match the diamond's characteristics, such as carat weight, cut, color, and clarity, with the details on the certificate. Many gemological labs also offer online verification services where you can enter the certificate number to confirm its authenticity.
